Text: Introduce noise into your statistics to protect privacy
Older Text: Introduce noise into your statistics to protect privacy

Text: This tool allows researchers to easily introduce noise into variables allowing them to mask specific details and keep data private. Find out howto get started with this tool below:
Older Text: This tool allows researchers to easily introduce noise into variables allowing them to mask specific details and keep data private. Find out howto get started with this tool below:

Text: Sign Up
Older Text: Sign Up

Text: Before starting, you have to make sure your data is appropriate to be processed with this tool by checking the following tips and terms of use.
Older Text: Before starting, you have to make sure your data is appropriate to be processed with this tool by checking the following tips and terms of use.

Text: Start the process
Older Text: Start the process

Text: When you log in you can start working with your Dataverse file. We’ll use the first 20 variables of your dataset.
Older Text: When you log in you can start working with your Dataverse file. We’ll use the first 20 variables of your dataset.

Text: Work on release
Older Text: Work on release

Text: You can work with your data in 4 steps: Confirm variables, Set epsilon value, Create statistics, Generate DP Release. You'll see more information about the steps during the process. You have 72 hours to finish your release or the data will be deleted from the tool.
Older Text: You can work with your data in 4 steps: Confirm variables, Set epsilon value, Create statistics, Generate DP Release. You'll see more information about the steps during the process. You have 72 hours to finish your release or the data will be deleted from the tool.

Text: Check the release
Older Text: Check the release

Text: Once you finish the steps, the file has to be processed and it can take minutes or hours. You’ll receive an email when it's done.
Older Text: Once you finish the steps, the file has to be processed and it can take minutes or hours. You’ll receive an email when it's done.

Text: Terms of Service
Older Text: Terms of Service

Text: Who should use this tool and why?
Older Text: Who should use this tool and why?

Text:
First, you have to review, adjust and confirm the variables of your dataset. These will be considered in the generation of
the differential privacy release. To adjust the necessary parameters to complete the process, you will need to set a valid
range depending on the variable's type in the table below.
Older Text:
First, you have to review, adjust and confirm the variables of your dataset. These will be considered in the generation of
the differential privacy release. To adjust the necessary parameters to complete the process, you will need to set a valid
range depending on the variable's type in the table below.

Text: E.g. Numerical: minX - max: Y; Categorical: cat1,cat2,cat3
Older Text: E.g. Numerical: minX - max: Y; Categorical: cat1,cat2,cat3

Text: Type is inferred. Edit it in the original file
Older Text: Type is inferred. Edit it in the original file

Text:
To determine the epsilon value, we need to confirm your dataset's characteristics with some questions about
the sample.
Older Text:
To determine the epsilon value, we need to confirm your dataset's characteristics with some questions about
the sample.

Text:
Epsilon is a metric of privacy loss at a differentially change in data (adding, removing 1 entry). The smaller the value is, the better
privacy protection.
Older Text:
Epsilon is a metric of privacy loss at a differentially change in data (adding, removing 1 entry). The smaller the value is, the better
privacy protection.

Text:
For example, information about persons, their behavior, beliefs and attributes is generally private information that individuals in
the dataset would not want publicly shared in their name and should be marked “yes”. Information that is solely about instituons,
corporations, natural phenomena, etc., that are public record and can be publicly distributed, does not depend on private
information.
Older Text:
For example, information about persons, their behavior, beliefs and attributes is generally private information that individuals in
the dataset would not want publicly shared in their name and should be marked “yes”. Information that is solely about instituons,
corporations, natural phenomena, etc., that are public record and can be publicly distributed, does not depend on private
information.

Text: For example, the number of observations in a dataset containing a 5% sample of California voters is public, but the number of observations in a dataset containing all cancer patients in a particular hospital may not be public, as it could be combined with auxiliary information to reveal whether or not a patient has cancer.
Older Text: For example, the number of observations in a dataset containing a 5% sample of California voters is public, but the number of observations in a dataset containing all cancer patients in a particular hospital may not be public, as it could be combined with auxiliary information to reveal whether or not a patient has cancer.

Text:
Create the statistics you would like to release. Please edit and confirm the degree of noise or interference you'd like to
add to the statistics.
Older Text:
Create the statistics you would like to release. Please edit and confirm the degree of noise or interference you'd like to
add to the statistics.

Text: Where should these links go?
Older Text: Where should these links go?

Text:
Changing the epsilon, delta, or confidence level will directly impact the privacy settings. We recommend
using the default values provided by the system
Older Text:
Changing the epsilon, delta, or confidence level will directly impact the privacy settings. We recommend
using the default values provided by the system

Text:
You can apply different statistics to single or multiples variables. Then, you can edit these statistics, lock them or delete
them.
Older Text:
You can apply different statistics to single or multiples variables. Then, you can edit these statistics, lock them or delete
them.

Text: Calculated error to be added to your statistic.
Older Text: Calculated error to be added to your statistic.

Text:
Changing the epsilon, delta, or confidence level will directly impact the privacy settings. We recommend
using the default values provided by the system
Older Text:
Changing the epsilon, delta, or confidence level will directly impact the privacy settings. We recommend
using the default values provided by the system

Text:
The recommended values below are based upon your dataset type selection
(i.e. “Information that could cause risk of harm to individuals or the university if
disclosed”)
Older Text:
The recommended values below are based upon your dataset type selection
(i.e. “Information that could cause risk of harm to individuals or the university if
disclosed”)

Text:
Note: Larger X corresponds to larger privacy loss budget, and hence, less privacy.
We do not recommend X exceding 1.
Older Text:
Note: Larger X corresponds to larger privacy loss budget, and hence, less privacy.
We do not recommend X exceding 1.

Text: Note: X is the probability of a blatant privacy violation. X values larger than the reciprocal of the dataset size are not allowed.
Older Text: Note: X is the probability of a blatant privacy violation. X values larger than the reciprocal of the dataset size are not allowed.

Text: The level of privacy protection for individuals in the dataset is governed by two privacy-loss parameters - x & x. Watch video to learn more.
Older Text: The level of privacy protection for individuals in the dataset is governed by two privacy-loss parameters - x & x. Watch video to learn more.

Text:
The final step is to submit the statistics and generate the differential privacy release. This will finalize the current
selections and spend your allocated privacy budget on them.
Older Text:
The final step is to submit the statistics and generate the differential privacy release. This will finalize the current
selections and spend your allocated privacy budget on them.
